item.title: Ruby turns 30
item.description:
#‚Äã643 ‚Äî March 2, 2023

Read on the Web

Ruby Weekly

Ruby Turns 30 Years Old; Celebrate with a Quine! ‚Äî Thirty years ago in a chat room far, far away, the name ‚ÄòRuby‚Äô came into being for Matz‚Äôs then-nascent language. This milestone has been celebrated by many including Matt Sears, DHH, Charles Nutter, in a (Japanese) ‚ñ∂Ô∏è audio message by Matz himself, and many others, but I had to feature this amazing effort to create a quine, of sorts, that works on ‚Äúall currently known CRubys‚Äù (right back to Ruby 0.49!). It‚Äôs worth hitting ‚ÄúTranslate to English‚Äù on this page to learn a few things about Ruby‚Äôs¬†history.

ku-ma-me

In his ‚ñ∂Ô∏è audio message, Matz acknowledges there are multiple ways you could define Ruby's birthday, but he's happy to go with the date it was named in this case.

Free eBook: Advanced Database Programming with Rails and Postgres ‚Äî Learn about subqueries, materialized views, and custom data types in Postgres and Rails. We walk through realistic real-life examples, translating first into SQL, and then into Rails code. Every example comes with source code so you can follow¬†along.

pganalyze sponsor

Improving the Developer Experience with the Ruby LSP ‚Äî Shopify continues to enhance the Ruby landscape, this time with a Ruby Language Server Protocol (LSP) server that takes advantage of recent performance improvements to Ruby (YJIT, etc.) and supports VS Code (or any editor that has LSP¬†support.)

Vinicius Stock (Shopify)

Introducing MRSK: A Way to Deploy Web Apps Anywhere ‚Äî The folks at 37Signals have developed a Capistrano replacement they're using for HEY‚Ä§com as part of their move to leave the cloud. In true DHH style, there's ‚ñ∂Ô∏è a screencast showing it off, but basically it's a way to deploy Docker containers, cloud or not.

David Heinemeier Hansson

There's more explanation on MRSK's very minimal¬†homepage.

QUICK BITS

  • Welcome to March 2023. This is the final month that Ruby 2.7 gets security releases. 2.7 goes EOL on March 31. It was such a good version.

  • Ruby Central is now sponsoring the development of Mastodon.

  • You can now add pronouns to your GitHub profile.

  • TIL that !value.nil? is a lot faster than value != nil

  • It looks like Drifting Ruby is doing ‚ñ∂Ô∏è a weekly video update on all things Rails over on YouTube.

  • üìÖ The 7th annual Rails Camp West is taking place this September in Hawaii. There's also a scholarship application if you need help to get¬†there.

üìï¬†Tutorials and Articles

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Building a Commercial Game Engine using mruby and SDL ‚Äî mruby is a lightweight, embeddable standardized Ruby implementation and the DragonRuby toolkit uses it at its heart. This talk digs into just how it works and why Ruby is a good fit for certain forms of game¬†development.

Amir Rajan

A Beginner's Guide to Ractors ‚Äî A quick, elementary introduction to ractors (once known as ‚Äòguilds‚Äô) which, in Ruby 3 and up, provide an actor-like concurrency abstraction for executing code in parallel without the problems introduced by¬†multi-threading.

Julie Kent

When Production Goes to üí© You Can‚Äôt Waste Time Digging for Errors ‚Äî Honeybadger helps you triage errors before your users can even report them. Get monitoring set up today in about 5¬†mins.

Honeybadger sponsor

Consider find_each for Looping Through Active Record Associations ‚Äî If you have many associated records (and you don‚Äôt care about order), find_each could be your¬†jam.

Andy Croll

What's Postgres Got to Do with AI? ‚Äî A look at using Ruby and OpenAI‚Äôs API to get embeddings for your data (recipes in this case), feeding (ha!) them into Postgres and storing and querying the resulting¬†vectors.

Christopher Winslett

What a Dev Firm Has Learnt Delivering Over 100 Ruby Projects ‚Äî Quite high¬†level/broad.
Tomasz Kania-Orze≈Ç

My Journey From Frustration with the JS Stack to Finding Joy in Ruby ‚Äî Nice to see folks heading this¬†way.
Devanil Junior

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Using AWS Lambda with Rails with Ken Collins
Remote Ruby podcast

üõ†¬†Code & Tools

mruby 3.2.0 Released ‚Äî mruby is a Matz-created lightweight alternative implementation of Ruby targeting situations where you might want to embed Ruby into other apps. For example, ngx_mruby lets you use Ruby within NGINX, and DragonRuby is built upon it¬†too (there's a talk about that¬†above).

mruby team

Ruby OpenAI Library Adds ChatGPT Support ‚Äî Yesterday, OpenAI added ChatGPT support to its API and this Ruby OpenAI client has rapidly added support for it too. Now you can integrate ChatGPT features into your Ruby apps and scripts with¬†ease.

Alex X

librtree-ruby: R-Tree Spatial Index Library ‚Äî A native (librtree-derived) extension for working with Guttman-Green R-tree spatial indexes ‚Äì a data structure enabling the fast querying of intersections of huge collections of¬†rectangles.

J.J. Green

Litestack: Embedded Services for Ruby Webapps ‚Äî It uses SQLite to provide a database, job processing and cache ‚Äòout of the box‚Äô and integrates with Rack, Sequel, Rails, etc. where they are present. Interesting¬†idea.

Mohammad A. Ali

Packwerk 3.0: Enforce Boundaries for More Modular Rails Apps ‚Äî A gem created at Shopify that can be used to enforce boundaries and modularize Rails applications. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è 1-minute screencast¬†demo.

item.title: Incredibly fast Ruby formatting
item.description:
#‚Äã642 ‚Äî February 23, 2023

Read on the Web

Ruby Weekly

The Case Against Monkey Patching (From a Rails Core Team¬†Member) ‚Äî Eileen (who we interviewed a couple of years ago) makes a solid case against monkey patching, what to do instead, and why refinements aren‚Äôt much better. She speaks from experience, so if you are living with a load of patches, follow Eileen out of the¬†quagmire.

Eileen Uchitelle

It's Official: The Standard Ruby VS Code Extension ‚Äî Standard is a Ruby style guide, linter and formatter created by TestDouble, and it now has a ‚Äòdistressingly fast‚Äô VS Code extension to really up the ante for almost real-time code¬†formatting.

Justin Searls (Test Double)

Introducing AppSignal for Hanami ‚Äî AppSignal integrates seamlessly with Hanami 2.0 to provide action-level insights, making it easier for you to ensure a smooth-running application. Monitor your Hanami app with a stroopwafel in your hand¬†üç™

AppSignal sponsor

'Whatever Happened to Ruby?' ‚Äî It‚Äôs not all sunshine and rainbows, but it‚Äôs always interesting to see a big outlet cover Ruby, and while Ruby isn‚Äôt exactly going to eat Java anymore, it has become entrenched in its niche. As Matthew Boeh is quoted: ‚ÄúRuby is never going to be the Next Big New Thing again, but I think it‚Äôs here to¬†stay.‚Äù

Josh Fruhlinger (Infoworld)

Creating an Intelligent Knowledge Base Q&A App with GPT-3 and¬†Ruby ‚Äî The example answers questions about a company by comparing the semantic values of questions to the text of different pages on the site, creating an AI-based FAQ of¬†sorts.

Kane Hooper

QUICK BITS

  • Remember how the Rails Foundation was formed and was looking for an executive director? Formerly of Hashicorp, Amanda Perino has landed the top job. Congratulations, Amanda!

  • Nick Schwaderer reported a Ruby 2.7 to 3.2 performance regression that has yet to be analyzed ‚Äì so if you're looking for something to do..

  • üìÖ Friendly.rb is a newly announced Ruby conference due to take place in Romania this September.

  • üìÖ Helvetic Ruby 2023 is a conference taking place in Switzerland this November and their Call for Speakers is open till March 31.

  • RubyGems.org is deprecating its Dependency API ‚Äì it's the way Bundler used to fetch dependency info between Bundler 1.1-1.12. If you've upgraded Bundler in the last several years and don't use the Dependency API directly in some unusual way, little will change for you.

üìï¬†Tutorials and Articles

How to Find a Memory Bloat in a Rails App Before It Happens ‚Äî Since most of the memory issues in an app happen around I/O (specifically, database I/O), if we ratio the data loaded to the response size, maybe we can find future sources of¬†bloat?

Dmitry Tsepelev

Duped Into Modifying a Frozen Hash ‚Äî Calling freeze on an object may not provide the immutability you expect. Kevin looks at a few nuances around freezing hashes and how HashWithIndifferentAccess can complicate¬†matters.

Kevin Murphy

üöÄ Monitor and Optimize Website Speed to Rank Higher in Google ‚Äî Monitor Google's Core Web Vitals and optimize performance using in-depth reports built for developers. Improve SEO &¬†UX.

DebugBear sponsor

You Don't Need Rails to Start Using Hotwire ‚Äî Hotwire, an ‚ÄòHTML over the wire‚Äô approach to making Web pages more dynamic (explained here), is closely tied to Rails, but Rails isn‚Äôt a must. Indeed, Akshay shows us how it can work on a totally static site¬†here.

Akshay Khot

Storing Ephemeral UI State with Kredis for Rails ‚Äî Kredis (Keyed Redis), an official Rails sub-project, wraps the usual Redis client library and simplifies working with structured data in the popular data¬†store.

Julian Rubisch

How Basecamp Stands to Save Millions From 'Cloud Exit' ‚Äî As 37signals runs some of the largest Rails apps out there, it‚Äôs interesting to see their rationale and plan to ‚Äòleave the cloud‚Äô for self-hosted infrastructure after many years on¬†AWS.

David Heinemeier Hansson

How Fly.io Will Use Rails 7.1's New Health Checks Feature ‚Äî Rails 7.1 is adding a discoverable app health check feature.

Sam Ruby

item.title: Getting Rustier with Ruby
item.description:
#‚Äã641 ‚Äî February 16, 2023

Read on the Web

Ruby Weekly

Magnus 0.5: A Way to Build Gems with¬†Rust ‚Äî Magnus enables the creation of Ruby extensions using Rust by providing an interface to Ruby‚Äôs usual C API. You can also embed Ruby in a Rust program. Numerous gems are now implemented with Magnus, including RuCaptcha, Selma, and polars-ruby.

Mat Sadler

Ruby Adds WebAssembly Support: What Does It Mean? ‚Äî Ruby 3.2 introduced the ability to target WebAssembly, so now you can write apps for any modern browser (and more) using Ruby. The future possibilities for WASM are¬†exciting.

Tomas Fernandez

Heroku Alternative - But On Any Cloud ‚Äî The convenience of Heroku, but on any cloud & in any region, with persistent storage, custom traffic rules, zero downtime deployments, blue/green & canary releases, WAF, & more. Try it today for free, plus $100 in credits with the code:¬†RubyWeekly100

Cloud 66 sponsor

Exploring the Sorbet Ruby Compiler ‚Äî Stripe first teased its Sorbet Ruby type checker almost five years ago (we mentioned it in issue 402!) but they‚Äôre also working on developing a performance focused ahead-of-time compiler for Ruby around¬†it..

Jeffery Morhous

Escaping/Encoding URI Components in Ruby 3.2 ‚Äî In Ruby 3.2, the standard library‚Äôs CGI gem gained two handy new methods: CGI.escapeURIComponent and CGI.unescapeURIComponent. CGI has long had a (heavily used) escape method, but these new methods tackle nuances in escaping strings to be included in path components or query¬†strings.

Jonathan Rochkind

What's New in Rails 7.1 ‚Äî There are a lot of small to medium additions and fixes, but the most exciting might be CTE support and much better Docker¬†support.

Emmanuel Hayford (AppSignal)

QUICK BITS

  • Emmanuel Hayford is one of the folks who puts together the weekly official Rails news digests and ‚ñ∂Ô∏è he went on the Ruby on Rails podcast to talk about that, the forthcoming Ruby 7.1, and Ruby 3.2.

  • Gift Egwuenu checks in with the latest monthly update on the RubyGems project looking at a busy month of releases both for RubyGems itself and the RubyGems.org¬†site.

  • Ruby Central gives us the lowdown on RubyConf 2023 taking place this April in Atlanta,¬†Georgia.

üìï¬†Tutorials and Articles

Ruby's private Keyword is Weird ‚Äî private in Ruby acts a little differently to private in most other object oriented languages. Jake also draws an interesting parallel between private methods and instance¬†variables.

Jake Zimmerman

My First Hanami App ‚Äî It‚Äôs great to see folks beginning to blog about picking up Hanami for building modern Ruby webapps. ‚ÄúHanami is a breath of fresh air‚Äù says¬†Karol.

Karol BƒÖk

External Garbage Collection ‚Äî ‚ÄúExternal‚Äù means connections and objects from third-party services or tools requiring disposal. Bradley goes through several approaches, combining a couple for the ‚ÄúCadillac‚Äù of external GC cleanup¬†jobs.

Bradley Buda (Census Engineering)

Want to Drastically Reduce the Risks in Hiring? Evaluate First! ‚Äî Work with well-trained engineers before committing to hiring. If they work out, keep them. If not, just let us¬†know.

Codeminer42 - Your Software Development Boutique sponsor

A Method's Gravity ‚Äî The author claims ‚ÄúThe bigger the method the more new lines of code will be added to it.‚Äù Hence gravity. Here Lucian tries to sell the idea of keeping methods short (or low gravity, if you¬†will).

Lucian Ghinda

Why Does 0.1 + 0.2 = 0.30000000000000004? ‚Äî Julia uses Python here but it applies to Ruby¬†too.

Julia Evans

Rails Initializers You Don't Know About: Inflections ‚Äî ‚ÄúInflections are rules that specify how words should be pluralized or singularized in a given¬†context.‚Äù
Keshav Biswa

Nate Berkopec
